addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

24 N
o
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
With
e Copies of
D. Casimirs
l
res
to
e
States
by
e Empero
rs
Commissioners./

page.lettertext:
fol.224r
May it please yo
r
good L. sins
e writing
of my letter of
e 16 of this moneth, wherein I
gave yo
w
to understand of D. Cassimires message
to some special persons in this place, about
e mater
of Pacification, there is nowe
at letter come
hither, w
ch
as then I advertised, was expected every
day to
e General states. Many men heere dis-
like it utterly, as if it were full of evident
tokens of his inward inclination to second the
Empero
r
:
whereby they are persuaded,
at he is
wonne unto it by a pension, or by somwhat in
reward: wherein
e Spaniard, it is thought, will
use any practise to speede of his purpose.
His letter was written in highe Dutche, wherof I
send yo
w
e copie, w
t
e Frenche translation.
It was delivered heere to some of
Holland,
of those
that are deputed, to open all suche letters, as
are directed to
e states. Howbeit as yet
they have nether thought it expedient, to acquaint
e Provinces w
t
it, nor to impart it to this Coun-
cell. It hath bin readde but by a fewe,
who are bent to suppresse it, and for ought I
can perceave, not to make any answear.
What course I shall folowe, for mine owne en-
devo
rs
, while this mater is in motion, I attend
to be instructed by yo
r
L. letters. All
that I am affraied of, is,
at if
e Generallitie
of this contrey, should be brought to accept a
treatie, suche conditions may be embraced,
as
upon some passion of
e people, and by some practise
fol.224v
of
e Spaniard, as may prejudice greatly bothe
themselves and their neighbours. Heere go-
eth a speeche
at
e
D. of Parma
is returned
from
e frontiers of
France
to
Brussels:
as
some men report, to conferre w
t
e Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs
: but as other men affirme, upon
intelligence had
at his government was besto-
wed upon
e old
Count Mansfeld
. How-
soever, it should seeme by all advertisments,
that he is greatly in disgrace w
t
e
K. of Spaine
If
e
Commissary Sparhawke
doe his diligence,
having had his dispatche
e 22 of this moneth
I hope
e companies required for
e service
of
Rouen,
will be there,
e winde serving, about
e end of this moneth.
And thus I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. N
o
24
1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
